lines.text: I was proud of my work. And the buildings went up. When they were finished the damnedest thing happened. It was like the buildings were too good for us. Nobody told us that. It just felt uncomfortable, that's all.
He's never tired. He's never miserable.
He's young.
When I was young I was tired and miserable.
Buon giorno, papa!
I'm not "papa." I'm your god-damned father.
What is this?
It's sauteed zucchini.
It's I-ty food. I don't want no I-ty food.
It's not. I got it at the A&P. It's like... squash.
I know I-ty food when I hear it! It's all them "eenie" foods... zucchini... and linguine... and fettuccine. I want some American food, dammit! I want French Fries!

[to the cat]
Oh, get off the table, Fellini!
Hey, that's *my* cat! His name's Jake, not Fellini! I won't have any "eenie" in this house!
[to the cat]
Your name's Jake, you understand?
I wonder if I have to have a job to qualify.
I don't think so. I think it's mostly blood and relatives that they're interested in.
Blood and relatives... well, that's great. I got both of them.
I dreamed all last night, that everyone I ever sold a car to came back for a refund. And there you were, handing out the checks! One for you, and one for you...
What's the matter?
He's shavin'.
Well... so what?
...his legs.
What are we gonna do about him?
I don't know dear. We could always strangle him while he's asleep.
Moocher, you're Catholic, right?
Yeah.
Did you ever go to confession?
Twice.
Did it make you feel better?
Once.
You guys still go swimmin' in the quarries?
Sure.
So, the only thing you got to show for my 20 years of work is the holes we left behind?
[Dave crosses himself on learning of Team Cinzano's imminent arrival]
Oh, Dave, try not to become Catholic on us.
Refund? Refund? Are you crazy! Refund? Refund? Refund?
How are you fellas doing?
Well, we're a little disturbed by developments in the Middle East, but...
Everybody cheats. I just didn't know.
Well, now you know.

[looking at Dave's beat up bike]
Doesn't look that bad to me...
That's cause you don't have to ride it!
Well, you know, you don't have to ride it either, Dave. We're not gonna beg you.
We may plead, but we would never beg!

[watching the college kids on campus]
Sure looks like they've got it made.
That's because they're rich.
Italians are poor, but they're happy.
Yeah? Maybe in Italy.
Have a nice trip.
You too.
But I'm not going anywhere.
I don't know about that.
You hear from your folks, Mooch?
Yeah, my dad called. He wanted to know if the house was sold. He could use the money something fierce.
Well, you can come and live with me when it's sold. In Italy, everybody lives together.

[laughs]
Since you won that Italian bike, man, you've been acting weird. You're really getting to think you're Italian, aren't you?
I wouldn't mind thinking I was somebody myself.
Hey! Are you really gonna shave your legs?
Certo! All the Italians do it.
Ah. Some country. The women don't shave theirs.
They're gonna keep callin' us "cutters." To them, it's just a dirty word. To me, it's just somethin' else I never got a chance to be.
I sure miss playing basketball. I got depressed as hell when my athlete's foot and jock itch went away.
That's the place to be right there, Wyoming! Nothin' but prairies and mountains and nobody around. All you need is your bed roll and a good horse.
Don't forget your toothbrush! You're still in your cavity-prone years.
You want to tell me who did it?
It was dark... All I can tell your for sure is that they all wore Brut after-shave and reeked of Lavoris.
No, I don't feel lucky to be alive! I feel lucky I'm not dead. There's a difference.
What's the matter? What are you cryin' for? I think you lost your wallet or something. I didn't want you to be this miserable. A little bit's all I asked for.

[after discovering that the college kids beat Cyril up]
They want a fight, we'll give 'em a fight.
We rednecks are few... college paleface students are many. I counsel peace.

You know what I'd like to be? A cartoon of some kind. You know, like when they get hit in the head with a frying pan or something, and their head looks like the frying pan, with the handle and everything? They they just go *booiing*
[shakes head]
and their head comes back to normal? Wouldn't that be great?
How'd you get to be so stupid, Cyril?
I don't know... I guess I just have a dumb heredity. What's your excuse, Michael?
Hey, come on in, Dave.
Nah, I read where this Italian coach said its no good to go swimmin' right after a race.
Who's swimmin'? I'm takin' a leak.
God-damned see-thru coffee!
He was very sickly until he started riding around on that bicycle.
Yeah... well... now his body's fine, but his mind is gone.
I was sure I was going to get that scholarship. My dad of course was sure I wasn't. When I didn't, he was real understanding, you know. He loves to do that. He loves to be understanding when I fail.
Pop, can I have this Saturday off?
Hell no!
Eh, just this once, Pop. The Italians are coming Saturday.
I don't care if the second coming's coming!
If you eat so much, Moocher, how come you're so damned small?
Oh... It's my metabolism. I eat 3 times a day and my metabolism eats 5 times a day.
You mean we might be a father?
No. I might be a father. And your mom might be a mother. And YOU might be a brother. See, that way I keep it all in the family.
Wow! Hey, I didn't think people your age...
The next word may be your last, kid!

[On the phone]
Oh, hi Rod, I just wanted you to know that there's some guy outside with a guitar serenading Kath!
You know what?
No, what?
I'm leaving home, that's what.
What? Where are you going?
About 5 blocks south.

[laughs]
Yeah?
I found this little place, it's so cute I could scream.
When you're 16 they call it Sweet 16 and when you're 18 you get to drink and and vote and see dirty movies. What the hell do you get to do when you're 19?
You leave home.
My Dad said that Jesus never went further than 50 miles from his home.
Well, look what happened to him.

[Dave rides by on his bicycle singing an Italian song]
He was as normal as pumpkin pie. And now, look at him. His poor parents.
Italianos - like the nightingales they sing. Like the eagles they fly!
Speakin' of flies, eh, you brought a helluva lot of flies in with ya.
You know what I'd like to be?
Smart.
Going to college must do somethin' to girls' tits, I swear. Just look at 'em.
[Yelling out the car]
Hi there! What's your major?
I wonder what its like to kiss a coed. I wonder about that a lot!

You know, I used to think I was a really great quarterback in high school. I still think so too. Can't even bring myself to light a cigarette, cause I keep thinkin' I gotta stay in shape. - You know what really gets me though? I mean, here I am, I gotta live in this stinkin' town and I gotta read in the newspapers about some hot shot kid - new star of the college team. Every year its gonna be a new one. And every year its never gonna be me. I'm just gonna be Mike. Twenty year old Mike. Thirty year old Mike. Old mean old man Mike.
You know, them college boys ain't so smart. I sold one of my worst cars to one of 'em today. They ain't too smart.
Well, I'm supposed to take this college entrance exam.
Are you gonna go to college?
Hell no. I just want to see if I can pass.
You haven't pledged any sorority yet?
No.
You should. Most frat guys won't go out with dormies. I'm the exception.
Say, you're on the swimming team, huh?
Yep. Breaststroke.
Mike, the time comes when we just all have to go our own ways, you know.
Oh, you're a real adult, aren't ya. B-town boy grows up.
The only thing I'm afraid of is wastin' the rest of my life with you guys!
I thought that was the whole plan. That we were going to waste the rest of our lives together.
Well, you could use some help. What if you gave him a job?
I don't want him sellin' used cars!
Why not? It's good enough for you.
Who says its good enough for me?
You do.
Damn right, it's good enough for me. But, I don't need any help. And he'd ruin me if I hired him. A weirdo kid like that. Jeez.
How you feelin'?
Tired, Pop.
Exhausted.
Yeah.
Good. Get used to it. From now on its gonna be more of the same. Let's go home.
So, you see, I think you really should go. I think you should come home, singing, with a trophy. I think you should do all those things while you can.
I win this one for you Mama.
Hell, I don't want to go to college Dad. To hell with them. I'm proud of being a cutter.
You're not a cutter. I'm a cutter.

[after Dave has taken his college entrance exam]
What? Are you afraid?
Yeah, a little bit. And then there's the rest of the guys.
Well, you took the exam. Did all right, didn't you?
Yes.
Well, that's - that's good.
I was thinking of taking French, but, it's my first year. Have you ever seen la Tour de France?
No.
No? Mon Dieu! The French riders - they're the best!

[Last lines]
Hi ya, big shot!
Bon jour, Papa!
